65.text: to its full size, with most of that growth taking place

68.text: in the first six months. The brain develops

71.text: in response to experience and to stimulation.

74.text: Every time a young baby learns something new --

79.text: to mimic a movement or a facial expression,

82.text: to pick something up, to form a word or to sit up --

86.text: new synaptic connections are being built in the brain.

94.text: They are quite rightly amazed and delighted by their children's cleverness.

125.text: It happens so naturally in most families

128.text: that we don't even notice it. Most of us are unaware

131.text: of its importance to human development and, by extension,

134.text: to the development of a healthy society.

137.text: And it's only when it goes wrong that we start to realize

140.text: the importance of families to children.

143.text: In August, 1993, I had my first opportunity to witness

147.text: on a massive scale the impact on children

151.text: of institutionalization and the absence of parenting.

155.text: Those of us who remember the newspaper reports

158.text: that came out of Romania after the 1989 revolution

161.text: will recall the horrors of the conditions in some of those institutions.

165.text: I was asked to help the director of a large institution to

168.text: help prevent the separation of children from their families.

172.text: Housing 550 babies, this was Ceausescu's show orphanage,

176.text: and so I'd been told the conditions were much better.

179.text: Having worked with lots of young children, I expected

182.text: the institution to be a riot of noise,

184.text: but it was as silent as a convent.

186.text: It was hard to believe there were any children there at all,

189.text: yet the director showed me into room after room,

192.text: each containing row upon row of cots,

195.text: in each of which lay a child staring into space.

201.text: In a room of 40 newborns, not one of them was crying.

205.text: Yet I could see soiled nappies, and I could see

207.text: that some of the children were distressed,

208.text: but the only noise was a low, continuous moan.

212.text: The head nurse told me proudly,

214.text: "You see, our children are very well-behaved."

218.text: Over the next few days, I began to realize

220.text: that this quietness was not exceptional.

222.text: The newly admitted babies would cry for the first few hours,

226.text: but their demands were not met, and so eventually

228.text: they learned not to bother. Within a few days,

231.text: they were listless, lethargic, and staring into space

236.text: Over the years, many people and news reports

239.text: have blamed the personnel in the institutions

241.text: for the harm caused to the children, but often, one member

244.text: of staff is caring for 10, 20, and even 40 children.

249.text: Hence they have no option but to implement a regimented program.

253.text: The children must be woken at 7 and fed at 7:30.

257.text: At 8, their nappies must be changed, so a staff member

259.text: may have only 30 minutes to feed 10 or 20 children.

262.text: If a child soils its nappy at 8:30, he will have to wait

266.text: several hours before it can be changed again.

269.text: The child's daily contact with another human being

272.text: is reduced to a few hurried minutes of feeding and changing,

276.text: and otherwise their only stimulation is the ceiling,

279.text: the walls or the bars of their cots.

283.text: Since my first visit to Ceausescu's institution,

286.text: I've seen hundreds of such places across 18 countries,

289.text: from the Czech Republic to Sudan.

319.text: These children are quickly labeled as having disabilities

321.text: and transferred to another institution for children with disabilities.

325.text: Most of these children will never leave the institution again.

329.text: For those without disabilities, at age three,

332.text: they're transferred to another institution, and at age seven,

334.text: to yet another. Segregated according to age and gender,

338.text: they are arbitrarily separated from their siblings,

341.text: often without even a chance to say goodbye.

345.text: There's rarely enough to eat. They are often hungry.

347.text: The older children bully the little ones. They learn to

350.text: survive. They learn to defend themselves, or they go under.

353.text: When they leave the institution, they find it really difficult

357.text: to cope and to integrate into society.

360.text: In Moldova, young women raised in institutions

364.text: are 10 times more likely to be trafficked than their peers,

368.text: and a Russian study found that two years after leaving institutions,

372.text: young adults, 20 percent of them had a criminal record,

379.text: and 10 percent had taken their own lives.

386.text: when there hasn't been a great deal of war or disaster in recent years?

409.text: Many countries have not developed inclusive schools,

412.text: and so even children with a very mild disability

415.text: are sent away to a residential special school,

419.text: The institution may be hundreds of miles away from the family home.

424.text: If the family's poor, they find it difficult to visit,

426.text: and gradually the relationship breaks down.

430.text: Behind each of the million children in institutions,

434.text: there is usually a story of parents who are desperate

437.text: and feel they've run out of options, like Natalia in Moldova,

443.text: who only had enough money to feed her baby,

445.text: and so had to send her older son to the institution;

448.text: or Desi, in Bulgaria, who looked after her four children

451.text: at home until her husband died,

454.text: but then she had to go out to work full time,

456.text: and with no support, felt she had no option

458.text: but to place a child with disabilities in an institution;

462.text: or the countless young girls too terrified to tell their parents

465.text: they're pregnant, who leave their babies in a hospital;

469.text: or the new parents, the young couple who have

472.text: just found out that their firstborn child has a disability,

476.text: and instead of being provided with positive messages

479.text: about their child's potential, are told by the doctors,

482.text: "Forget her, leave her in the institution,

485.text: go home and make a healthy one."

488.text: This state of affairs is neither necessary nor is it inevitable.

492.text: Every child has the right to a family, deserves

495.text: and needs a family, and children are amazingly resilient.

499.text: We find that if we get them out of institutions and into loving

502.text: families early on, they recover their developmental delays,

505.text: and go on to lead normal, happy lives.

508.text: It's also much cheaper to provide support to families

512.text: than it is to provide institutions.

514.text: One study suggests that a family support service

518.text: costs 10 percent of an institutional placement,

526.text: If we spend less on these children but on the right services,

529.text: we can take the savings and reinvest them in high quality

533.text: residential care for those few children with extremely complex needs.

537.text: Across Europe, a movement is growing to shift the focus

542.text: and transfer the resources from large institutions

545.text: that provide poor quality care to community-based services

549.text: that protect children from harm and allow them to develop

551.text: to their full potential. When I first started to work in Romania

555.text: nearly 20 years ago, there were 200,000 children living

559.text: in institutions, and more entering every day.

563.text: Now, there are less than 10,000, and

565.text: family support services are provided across the country.

568.text: In Moldova, despite extreme poverty and the terrible effects

572.text: of the global financial crisis, the numbers of children

575.text: in institutions has reduced by more than 50 percent

578.text: in the last five years, and the resources are being

581.text: redistributed to family support services and inclusive schools.

586.text: Many countries have developed national action plans for change.

589.text: The European Commission and other major donors

591.text: are finding ways to divert money from institutions

598.text: to look after their own children.

601.text: But there is still much to be done to end the systematic

606.text: Awareness-raising is required at every level of society.

609.text: People need to know the harm that institutions cause to children,

612.text: and the better alternatives that exist.

615.text: If we know people who are planning to support orphanages,

618.text: we should convince them to support family services instead.

622.text: Together, this is the one form of child abuse

626.text: that we could eradicate in our lifetime.
